node.accessibility_caption: The Laguna Meadow Trail lined with wildflowers.

node.text:
Have you hiked the Laguna Meadow Trail during the summer monsoon season? The wildflowers are spectacular! Start early so you can get back down the mountain before the afternoon thunderstorm lets loose. 
Image: Laguna Meadow Trail lined with wildflowers. 
NPS/CA Hoyt #BigBend #ChisosMountains #summerrain #wildflowers #hiking #findyourpark #encuentratuparque

node.accessibility_caption: A large group of red lady bugs are gathered on a pale colored boulder.

node.text:
The ladybug swarms are back! Hikers on the Emory Peak trail are reporting large masses of them gathering on the rocks and trees near the end of the trail. 

In the summer months, thousands of ladybugs gather on high mountain peaks, forming a red or black cover on rocks and trees. These beetles appear to cluster at high elevations all over the southwestern U.S. for reasons that are not clearly understood. Some scientists believe the ladybugs fly to high elevations to escape extreme temperatures, for mating purposes, or to avoid competition for food with their larvae.

The cuties pictured here are native Convergent Lady Beetles, also call ladybugs or lady-bird beetles. If you look closely, you can see water droplets still hanging on their shells after a brief rain. The magic is in the details!

What is your most memorable lady bug encounter?

📷: courtesy of C. Hamilton
#bigbend #bigbendnationalpark #ladybugs #summer

node.accessibility_caption: Four Turkey Vultures and one Northern Cardinal are sitting on branches in a dead tree.

node.text:
Birds of a different feather sometimes flock together. Do you see the bird who has joined the vulture committee?

Groups of vultures go by different names, depending on what activity they are undertaking at that moment. Vultures circling overhead are called a "kettle", while a group of vultures perched in a tree are known as a "committee". The most humorous and descriptive noun is a group of vultures feeding on carrion, which is called a "wake". 

Perhaps there should be a term for a group of vultures vomiting on your vehicle as they try to fly up and away from the carrion they were eating on the side of the road. Yes, this can happen, and is a great reason to give them plenty of room and respect! 

📷: NPS/C. Negele
#bigbend #bigbendnationalpark #turkeyvulture #cardinal #birdbuddies

node.accessibility_caption: A shrub with large yellow flowers is growing on a hillside. Clay hills with the colors white, red, and purple are visible in the background.

node.text:
During the month of August, Big Bend National Park will offer two Fee Free Days. The first free entry day will happen on Wednesday, August 4th, marking the first anniversary of the Great American Outdoors Act. The second free entry day will be Wednesday, August 25th in honor of the National Park Service's 105th birthday!

📷:NPS/B. Trester
#bigbend #bigbendnationalpark #feefreeday #trumpetflower

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Big Bend National Park on July 31, 2021. May be an image of nature and mountain.

node.text:
Park rangers wear many different hats. A ranger's day might begin with the presentation of a program to park visitors, requiring the ranger to wear a "flat hat", the iconic brown Stetson hat. Afternoon could find the same ranger assisting with a plant survey, which means doffing the flat hat and donning a green ball cap or work hat. And if an emergency were to arise where extra hands were needed, the cap would be traded for a bright yellow helmet. 

The National Park Service uniform website has eight different styles of hats, including a balaclava. What is the most interesting hat you have worn while at work?

Photo credit: NPS/J. Jurado
Photo description: Six people work together to maneuver a wheeled litter containing an injured person down a rocky trail.
#worldrangerday #bigbend #bigbendnationalpark #grapevinehills #ranger #rangerhat

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Big Bend National Park on July 22, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and outdoors.

node.text:
We are proud to introduce Antonia Perez, Historic Preservation Intern at Big Bend National Park for the past 11 months. Antonia grew up in Fort Worth, Texas, but her family has ties to this area. Antonia's great grandmother's family was from Boquillas, Texas, and her great grandmother's husband, son, and daughter's husband (Papa Mando) all worked at Big Bend. For Antonia, the opportunity to experience the region her mom grew up in, as well as follow her personal passion for historic preservation proved irresistible. 

Antonia's list of duties is intriguing, beginning with maintenance, monitoring, and minor restoration to historic structures. Along with other Cultural Resource interns, she completed Designations of Eligibility for the National Register on several structures in the park. A project she is most proud of was creating a Historic Preservation Maintenance Plan for the Rio Grande Village Cultural Landscape. 

During her time in the park, Antonia learned how to canoe, identify archeological artifacts, make adobe, and enjoy living in a remote location. Antonia's passion for her work and her positive experiences working with other park employees is immediately evident. She urges us to reach out and utilize co-workers' knowledge, skills, and willingness to volunteer with projects. The National Park Service community is an incredible resource, composed of people with many different backgrounds and experiences. 

Antonia hopes to continue with hands-on care of historic structures and is considering the Traditional Trades Apprenticeship Program with the National Park Service. She reminds us that we all share the responsibility of protecting and caring for our nation's historic resources. 

Thank you, Antonia, for your hard work and commitment to Big Bend over the past year. We wish you the very best, and hope to see you in the park again in the future!

Photo description: Antonia stands inside an adobe structure next to a wheelbarrow filled with adobe mud, providing instructions to a group of volunteers.
📷: NPS/R. Gupman
#latinoconservationweek #bigbend #bigbendnationalpark  #adobe #historicpreservation #alvinohouse

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Big Bend National Park in Big Bend National Park. May be an image of black bear and nature.

node.text:
When hiking in the Chisos, it’s a good idea to look up occasionally. You never know what’s overhead!
This sow and her two cubs were sleeping through the heat of the day high in an oak tree. She was strategically placed. Anything after her cubs would have to go through her from the front. Any cub wanting to wander would have to pass her from behind. An experienced Mama!

#blackbear #ChisosMountains #NapTime #BigBend #FindYourPark 
Image taken with a long lens and cropped/CA Hoyt

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Big Bend National Park on July 20, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
“The astronauts' better physical condition annoyed the geologists throughout the geology training course. Some of the instructors started running and exercising regularly, but it always seemed the astronauts were far ahead of us.”

-Dr. Elbert A King, Jr. 

Did you know that national parks have been used as analogs to train astronauts for future missions to other worlds? Dr. King was a professor of geology at the University of Houston, lamenting the physical fitness of NASA astronauts as he taught them how to take geologic samples. In the 1960s, astronauts travelled to experience earthly extremes, learn to recognize basic types of rock, and practice communicating in the field at some familiar sites: the Grand Canyon, Valles Caldera, Katmai, and Big Bend National Park, among others. The 1964 trip to Big Bend focused on volcanic rocks, geologic mapping, and stratigraphy. Dr. King described the trip:

“Like the Grand Canyon, Big Bend is a beautifully wild place, particularly in the springtime before the full heat of summer arrives… There were many lessons to learn in Big Bend. One was discovered by Neil Armstrong, who hit a basalt outcrop with his rock hammer and was cut slightly on the arm by a flying rock chip. This was not the correct way to collect rock samples, either on the Earth or the Moon. Even a small cut in a space suit could have serious consequences.” 

Big Bend has had many lessons for us all, from researchers and teachers to astronauts and casual explorers. The wild desert landscape often does look otherworldly, especially in the silence and serenity that come with being far from things like highways and cities. 

Happy anniversary to Apollo 11, and to all of us for our own giant leaps. 

(Excerpts from King, Elbert A. Moon Trip: A Personal Account of the Apollo Program and Its Science. University of Houston, 1989.) 

Image description: A 1969 image shows Buzz Aldrin and Neil Armstrong studying a rock sample in the desert of west Texas. 
Image credit: NASA

#Apollo11 #NASA #BigBend #bigbendnationalpark

Photo by Big Bend National Park on July 18, 2021. May be an image of flower and nature.

node.text:
"A flower blooming in the desert has greater strength than a tree flourishing in a rain forest." - Matshona Dhliwayo

It takes a certain skill set for a plant to survive, much less bloom, in the Chihuahuan desert! This beauty is a cenizo, often called Texas Sage or Texas Ranger, although it is not actually a sage. They are extremely drought and heat tolerant, and sport their green-gray leaves year-round. Cenizo need sunny, well-drained, alkaline, rocky soil to thrive - perfect for West Texas! 

Cenizo are sometimes called "barometer bush" since their flowering is triggered by high humidity or soil moisture after rains. They are currently blooming in areas of the park that have seen recent rains, and they immediately catch your eye as you're driving down the road.

Image description: A medium-size shrub sporting pink blooms is growing on a hillside. High mountains rise up in the background.
📷: NPS/C. Negele
#bigbend #bigbendnationalpark #cenizo #chisosmountains #summerrains
